Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Situation2: A patient has arrived at the emergency room with a severe, fast-spreading infection that requires an immediate and powerful antibiotic treatment.
Story: My phone buzzed violently on the nightstand, jolting me awake. I saw my friend’s name flashing on the screen, and when I answered, her voice was raw with tears. She could barely speak, choking out that something terrible had happened to her family. I sat up, heart pounding, trying to listen, to be the friend she needed—someone who would stay on the line, offer comfort, and just be there. But as I murmured soothing words, my hospital pager blared. An emergency: a patient in the ER with a rapidly spreading infection, needing immediate intervention. I was the only doctor on call. My mind raced. My friend’s pain was real and urgent, but so was the life in my care. I felt torn in two, the weight of both worlds pressing down on me. My friend needed me to listen, to stay, to care. My patient needed me to act, to decide, to save. I stared at the phone, the pager, my own trembling hands, caught between the impossible expectations of being a good friend and a responsible doctor.
